title: 'Social value' is good business for BHP
text:
Mackenzie’s view, which was amplified by Healy overnight, is that BHP’s scope III investment is both rational and commercial.

In a past life Healy had a reputation as one of Australia’s leading commercial litigators and courtroom performers. His mission on Tuesday was to prosecute the case that investment against the ever-evolving slate of challenges to social licence was, above all, “good business”.

“We believe we must move from ‘social licence’ to ‘social value’; Or from ‘tolerance and acceptance’ to ‘trust and partnership’,” Healy said.

“We know this will be a challenging evolution. Today, I am going to explain why this transition – from licence to value – underpins our strategy.

A disorderly transition to decarbonisation has the potential to threaten the viability of entire commodities in our product suite. — Geoff Healy, chief external affairs officer BHP

“And it is on this point that I want to be very clear. For us, it is – plain and simple – good business,” he said.

The BHP logic is that demonstrating a sector-leading wealth of social value opens access to the best resources, markets, talent pools, commercial partners and the richest, most secure capital markets.

BHP is a very large company that draws its financial power from comparatively few, very large, long-term assets that are “structurally immobile”, Healy observed before noting that any level of “imbalance” in community relations carried the potential of fundamental effect on BHP and its owners.

Advertisement

Healy described just how intimate BHP’s world really is, noting about 80 per cent of its EBITDA is harvested from just three regions: Western Australia, Queensland and the northern Atacama desert of Chile.

“Our portfolio is simple, yet the inherent risks are complex and wide-ranging,” he said.

Those risks start with the sorts of things we have seen in Australia often enough over the past three decades, things like attempts to retrospectively reset fiscal arrangements or to refuse approvals for projects new and old.

At their peak though, the risks triggered by a collapse of social value are “existential”, Healy proposed.

“A disorderly transition to decarbonisation has the potential to threaten the viability of entire commodities in our product suite.

“And a social and environmental disaster, such as another significant tailings dam failure, has the potential to be existential.

“But on the flipside, we know that if we manage well our transition – from ‘licence to value’ – we will create a core competitive advantage that will be very hard to replicate,” he said.

Spark's darkest fears

Advertisement

Spark Infrastructure’s darkest fears about the price it will be able to charge for access to its electricity network have played out pretty much as chief executive Rick Francis predicted in August.

Back then the Spark boss predicted something akin to an investment strike given the likelihood that new rate of return guidance from the Australian Energy Regulator would play out in the regulator’s extant access pricing rulings.

The Francis threat, which arrived as an immediate and wry postscript to the Treasurer’s call for Australian business to open their wallets and start investing again in the economy, was based on Spark’s modelling of new rate of return guidance from the energy market regulator.

Francis said that when Spark ran its numbers through the new AER model it generated a rate of return ceiling of around 4.6 per cent. “I would get laughed out of the room if I went to my owners and offered that as a proposition,” Francis told The Australian Financial Review.

On Tuesday the AER delivered draft advice on the regulated return Spark can extract from its SA Power Networks business through the years 2020-2025. Spark can extract $3.905 billion over that five-year stretch. That is $309 million less than the $4.214 billion that Spark figured was needed.

Spark responded to the draft ruling by signalling an intent to fully test the AER’s draft ruling and repeating, in rather more diplomatic and formal terms, the intent of Francis’ August complaint.

“Spark Infrastructure reiterates its view that the rate of return is not adequate to provide both a competitive and predictable return to long-term owners of network assets as required under the National Electricity and Gas objectives.

“This puts at risk efficient investment in energy network assets, to the long-term detriment of consumers,” Spark said in a statement released through the ASX platform.

Advertisement

“It is disappointing that the AER has not acted on the clear message it has received from the investment community in relation to the market’s rate of return expectations. In our view, the rate of return is insufficient to ensure the long-term sustainability and reliability of Australia’s electricity infrastructure.

"This jeopardises achievement of Australia’s environment and energy policy objectives. Our country needs critical investment in networks to facilitate the economy’s efficient transition to a renewable future, and the integration of distributed energy resources enabling consumer choice and delivering the lowest-cost system,” Francis said on Tuesday.

To give you an idea of the risk Spark was talking about, consider again what Francis told us back in August.

“Currently, what we have here in front of us is the first major build out of the transmission network in decades and there is inherent risk associated with those greenfields construction projects like, say, a $1.5 billion investment in linking South Australia to the NSW grid," Francis warned in August.

Spark sits either side of the interconnector proposal given it operates both the SA and NSW networks.

The other part of the network investment story is that the gathering roll-out of renewable generation demands a network that reaches further and is more flexible at every level of its operation.

The AER’s draft ruling, which will now endure a review period that will result in a final decision by 30 April next year, allows for a weighted average cost of capital of 4.95 per cent.

That WACC is a little bit higher than the Spark modelling might have anticipated but it is a significant retreat from the 6.17 per cent allowed for in the 2015-20 ruling.

Advertisement

“This decrease is driven by changes we made to our regulatory tax approach and the 2018 rate of return instrument,” the AER advised on Tuesday.

“The biggest contributor to the difference between our draft decision and SA Network’s proposal is the current rate of return (and therefore the rate of return on capital),” the regulator continued.

“Whilst SA Power Networks applied the 2018 rate of return instrument and proposed a 5.43 per cent rate of return, currently the risk-free rate and cost of debt is lower than at the time of its proposal, leading to a rate of return of 4.95 per cent.

“Consequently, the revenue for the cost of capital component is lower by $233 million compared to the SA Power Network’s proposal,” the AER said.

The AER estimated lower network returns will trim $20 annually from the average SA consumer’s power bill and $90 annually for small business customers.

And that will be good as long as the system remains secure enough for the lights to stay on.
description: Australia's resources champion says “a disorderly" transition to a low-carbon world has the potential to threaten the viability of entire commodities in its product suite.
